data.text: A fine or very thin thread or fiber.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: filaments of cloth; filaments of flax.

data.text: A slender or threadlike structure or part, especially.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A fine wire that is heated electrically to produce light in an incandescent lamp.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The stalk that bears the anther in the stamen of a flower.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A chainlike series of cells, as in many algae.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A long thin cellular structure characteristic of many fungi, usually having multiple nuclei and often divided by septa.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various long thin celestial objects or phenomena, such as a solar filament.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: In geometrical topics, a movable object which at any one instant, or indivisible determination of time, is at every part of a line. During a lapse of time a filament is restricted to being in some surface, which it is said to generate.

A fine untwisted thread; a separate fiber or fibril of any vegetable or animal tissue or product, natural or artificial, or of a fibrous mineral: as, a filament of silk, wool, cobweb, or asbestos; a cortical or muscular filament.
